metadata.title: Enantioselective trifluoromethylthiolation of 4-substituted pyrazolones catalyzed by amide-based phase transfer catalysts

Enantioselective trifluoromethylthiolation of 4-substituted pyrazolones catalyzed by amide-based phase transfer catalysts Yakun Wang Conceptualization Methodology Formal analysis Data curation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Visualization Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ Shuaifei Wang Methodology Validation a Yingying Wang Methodology Validation a Yufeng Wu Formal analysis Data curation b Jie Liu Formal analysis a Kedi Zhou Validation a Qichen Sun Validation a Lizhen Fang Writing – original draft a Tao Zhang Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ a School of Pharmacy, Xinxiang Medical University, Xinxiang, Henan 453003, PR China School of Pharmacy Xinxiang Medical University Xinxiang Henan 453003 PR China aSchool of Pharmacy, Xinxiang Medical University, Xinxiang, Henan 453003, PR China b School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning 116024, PR China School of Chemical Engineering Dalian University of Technology Dalian Liaoning 116024 PR China bSchool of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning 116024, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. We successfully developed the first enantioselective trifluoromethylthiolation of 4-substituted pyrazolones catalyzed by amide-based Cinchona alkaloids with N-trifluoromethylthiosaccharin. A broad variety of chiral CF3S-pyrazolones were obtained in excellent yields with high enantioselectivities. Controlled experiments showed that the multiple hydrogen bonding interactions and the steric hindrance at NH-position were indispensable for high enantioselectivity and reactivity. Furthermore, these amide-based phase transfer catalysts could be easily recovered and reused for such a reaction with almost original reactivity and enantioselectivity. Graphical abstract Enantioselective trifluoromethylthiolation of 4-substituted pyrazolones has been developed by amide-based phase transfer catalysts Image, graphical abstract Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Over the past several decades, fluorinated organic molecules played significant roles in medicinal chemistry, agrochemistry and fine chemistry, because fluorine can great change the physical and biological properties of organic molecules [1]. More specifically, the introduction of electron-withdrawing trifluoromethylthio group (SCF3) has been well known to be fascinating, based on the fact that the SCF3 group has expressively high Hansch's hydrophobicity parameter (π=1.44) with outstanding lipophilicity. These advantages can change the pharmacokinetics and physicochemical properties of drug molecules, and improve metabolic stabilities [2]. Various methods have been developed for introducing SCF3 group into organic molecules [3]. In contrast, asymmetric construction of SCF3 group at C(sp3) centres has received less attention and remains as a challenging task [4]. To date, enantioselective electrophilic trifluoromethylations of carbonyl compounds [5] and alkenes [6] were developed to construct SCF3 contained chiral centers. Furthermore, enantioselective nucleophilic trifluoromethylthiolationshad been also developed in recent years [7]. Thus, the development of practical strategies and expansion of the diversified substrate classes for chiral trifluoromethylthiolated compounds is highly desirable. On the other hand, pyrazolones are one of the most important classes of nitrogen-nitrogen bonds containing heterocycles, they have been widely applied in medicinal chemistry and functional materials [8], such as antibacterial agents [9] and inhibitor of carboxylesterase 2 [10]. Great efforts in asymmetric synthesis of chiral pyrazolone and its derivatives have been made in recent years [11]. Until now, the enantioselective hydroxylation [12], sulfenylation [13], chlorination [14], fluorination [15] and amination [16] have been successfully developed to construct chiral 4-heteroatom-substituted pyrazolones. However, there are no enantioselective approach for the synthesis of chiral SCF3 substituted pyrazolone skeleton as far as we known. Given the importance of both SCF3 unit and the pyrazolone scaffold, the development of new strategies to synthesize chiral 4-SCF3 pyrazolones are quite essential. Herein, we disclose the first enantioselective trifluoromethylthiolation of 4-substituted pyrazolone catalyzed by amide-based Cinchona alkaloid derived phase-transfer catalysts (Scheme 1 ). Experimental section General methods Unless otherwise stated, all commercial reagents and solvents were used without further additional purification. Analytical TLC was visualized with UV light at 254 nm. Thin layer chromatography was carried out on TLC aluminum sheets with silica gel 60 F254 plates. Purification of reaction products was carried out with chromatography on silica gel (200–300 mesh). 1H NMR (400 MHz), 13C NMR (126 MHz) and 19F NMR (376 MHz) were recorded on a VARIAN INOVA-400 M at 25 °C. Chemical shifts are reported as δ (ppm) values relative to TMS as internal standard and coupling constants (J) in Hz. HPLC analyses were performed on equipped with Daicel Chiralpak AD-H, AS-H, IA-H or OJ-H chiral column (0.46 cm × 25 cm), using mixtures of n-hexane/isopropyl alcohol as mobile phase, at 25 °C. Mass spectra were measured by using electron ionization and electrospray ionization techniques. Melting points were determined with a hot plate apparatus. Optical rotations were measured on a digital polarimeter with a sodium lamp at 25 °C. PTC 3a-3f were easily prepared according to the previous papers [24]. 3 g, 3 h, 3j, 3l, 3 m, 3o, 3 ga, 3 gb were prepared according to previous paper [15b]. 4-Sustitued pyrazolones 1a-1ac were prepared from acetophenone and β-keto esters according to previous literature [12]. 2a was prepared from saccharin according to the literature [17]. 2b, 2c were purchased from Leyan reagent. 2d was prepared according to literature [23]. General proceduce for synthesis of hybrid amide-based PTC To the solution of Cinchona alkaloids in THF (30 mL), the corresponding amide (3.4 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 2–4 h and the reaction was controlled using TLC. Subsequently the solvent was evaporated under vacuum and the solid residue was dissolved in dichloromethane (2 mL). The solution of crude catalyst was added dropwise with diethyl ether (15 mL). Then the precipitate was filtered, washed with diethyl ether (10 mL) and dried. PTC were obtained in a form of solids. General proceduce for achiral trifluoromethylthiolation of pyrazolones Reactions were conducted with pyrazolone 1 (0.1 mmol) in the presence of PTC 3a (5 mol%) in Et2O (2 mL). Then K2CO3 (0.3 mmol) and N-Trifluoromethylthiosaccharin 2a (0.12 mmol) was added, the reaction was stirred at 5 °C for 2–12 h. After completion of the reaction (confirmed by TLC analysis), the solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the reside was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (ethyl acetate/petroleum ether 5:1 to 25:1) to provide the corresponding products. The ee values of the products were determined by chiral HPLC. General proceduce for asymmetric trifluoromethylthiolation of pyrazolones Reactions were carried out with pyrazolone 1 (0.1 mmol), PTC 3 u (2.5 mol%) and 50% CH3COOK (0.2 mL) in toluene (2 mL) at −20 °C, then N-Trifluoromethylthiosaccharin 2a (0.12 mmol) was added. The reaction was stirred at −20 °C for 4 h. After completion of the reaction (confirmed by TLC analysis), the solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the reside was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (ethyl acetate/petroleum ether 5:1 to 25:1) to provide the corresponding products. The ee values of the products were determined by chiral HPLC. Results and discussion We began the present study with enantioselective trifluoromethylthiolation of pyrazolone 1a as the model substrate, the shelf-stable N-Trifluoromethylthiosaccharin (2) as the trifluoromethylthiolated reagent [17]. The anticipated product 4a was obtained in 67% yield with 38% K2HPO4 after 12 h in toluene (Table 1 , entry 1). Phase transfer catalysis was recognized as effective and sustainable method [18], and the visible light-promoted enantioselective aerobic oxidation of pyrazolones by phase transfer catalysis was achieved not long ago [19]. So we then screened different kinds of Cinchona alkaloid derived phase transfer catalysts (Fig. 1 ). We screened the simple N-benzyl PTC 3a, the biquaternary ammonium salt 3b, the quinoline-N-oxide PTC 3c, the anthracyl substituted PTC 3d-3e, and the C-2′-arylated PTC 3f, but these results were not satisfactory (Table 1, entries 2–7). To our delight, the ee value was increased to 38% when amide-based PTC 3 g [20]was used (Table 1, entry 8). To further optimize the catalyst structure of this enantioselective reaction, a series of Cinchona alkaloid-derived amide-based phase-transfer catalysts were then synthesized and screened. Neither electron-donating group (3 h) nor the electron drawing group (3i) could improve the enantioselectivity (Table 1, entries 9–10). Further, we found the steric hindrance group at ortho-position in benzene ring could ulteriorly improve the enantioselectivity (Table 1, entries 11–13). To our delight, introducing the t-Bu group at -NH position afforded 4a with 59% ee in 97% yield (Table 1, entry 14). Then we tried to increase the steric hindrance at -NH position, and 1-Ad, diphenyl and dimethyl phenyl groups were then introduced, but the enantioselectivities were moderate (Table 1, entries 15–19). However, 3 s with free hydroxyl group showed poor results (Table 1, entry 20).To our delight, the triphenyl substituted PTC 3t worked well and gave 4a with 63% ee and 96% yield after 2 h (Table 1, entry 21). The quinidine derived PTC 3 u provided 4a with higher enantioselectivity (70% ee) (Table 1, entry 22). Finally, the cinchonidine and quinine derived PTC 3 u and 3v afforded high enantioselectivities (65–66% ee) and provided the reversed S-product of 4a (Table 1, entries 23–24). To our delight, 50% CH3COOK provided 4a with 75% ee (Table 1, entry 25). Ee value was improved to 82% when the reaction temperature was decreased to −20 °C (Table 1, entry 26). Furthermore, the enantioselectivity could be increased to 83% ee when the substrate concentration was reduced to 0.05 M, and the loading of catalyst 3 u could be reduced to as low as 2.5 mol%, while still achieving 95% yield in 4 h (Table 1, entry 27). Hence, the reaction parameters listed in entry 27 were selected as the optimal reaction conditions for the next investigations. Inspired by these exciting results, we turned our attention to the unique reactivity of trifluoromethylthiolation reagent and carried out some comparison experiments using other electrophilic SCF3 reagents 2b-2d As described in Scheme 2 , N-(trifluoromethylthio)-succinimide 2b [21], N-(trifluoromethylthio)-phthalimide 2c [22] and N-Trifluoromethylthio-dibenzene-sulfonimide 2d [23]showed lower reactivity towards 1a, and the desired product 4a was obtained in low to moderate yields (32–74%) and enantioselectivities (42–67% ee). These results highlighted the unique feature and advantage of 2a as a good candidate for enantioselective trifluoromethylthiolation of pyrazolone under phase transfer catalysis (Fig. 2 ). With these optimized conditions in hand, we next investigated the generality of this reaction (Scheme 3 ). Initially, with the benzyl group at C-4-position, the substituent effect of the aryl ring was investigated. The electron donating and electron withdrawing groups were both tolerated, such as OMe, CF3, CN, NO2, F, Cl, Br and naphthyl, affording the corresponding products (4b-4o) in excellent yields (83–97% yield) with good ee (71–85%). Allyl, propargyl at C-4-position provided 4p and 4q in 70–82% ee. However, methyl substitution at C-4-position exhibited moderate levels of enantioselectivities (41% ee, 4r). Then we investigated the substituted groups at C-3-position. 1 s with methyl group at C-3-position afforded 4 s with moderate enantioselectivity (48% ee) in 92% yield. Remarkably, 4-CF3, 4-Cl, 4-CN, 4-Me, 4-isopropyl, 3, 5-di-OMe, 3,5-di-CF3, in aryl ring at C-3 position were all well-tolerated and the chiral products (4t-4aa) were obtained in 89–95% yields with 75–88% ee. Finally we investigated the influence of the N-substituents, but the 4-CF3 and perfluorinated products (4ab and 4ac) were obtained in 59–73% ee. After all, we demonstrated the good substrate universality of 4-substituted pyrazolones (29 examples) for asymmetric electrophilic trifluoromethylthiolation. To test the scale-up potential of our methodology, a 0.8 g sample (2 mmol) of pyrazolone 1y was treated with 2a (0.68 g, 2.4 mmol) and PTC 3 u (0.036 g, 2.5 mol%) in toluene and 50% CH3COOK aqueous solution. After 4 h, the reaction was completed and the chiral product was obtained by chromatography in 91% yield with 85% ee. The enantioselectivity of 4y could be improved to 95% ee after recrystallization in ethanol. Fortunately, single crystal of 4y was obtained for X-ray crystallographic analysis, whose absoluteconfiguration was explicitly determined to be R (Scheme 3). On this basis, the other chiral products from this reaction were assumed to have the same (R)-configuration. It is worth mentioning that PTC 3 u is abysmally insoluble in diethyl ether at room temperature, and it can be easily recovered by filtration (once the reaction was completed, after separation of the base by liquid separation, evaporation of the solvent and addition of ethyl ether). The recovered ammonium salt has been reused up to six times in the model reaction (Scheme 3), giving rise to almost identical yields and enantioselectivities of 4y (Scheme 3). In order to further understand the structure-activity relationship between catalyst structure and reaction reactivity, we screened a series of 9-OH and -NH modified Cinchona alkaloids. First, product 4a was obtained with 49% ee in 93% yield when the simple amide-based PTC 3 g was used. Then 3 ga was introduced (C-9 OH group was protected by benzyl), the reaction rate is decreased significantly, and 4a was obtained with 31% yield in 9% ee. Analogously, 4a was obtained with 65% yield in 16% ee when 3 gb was used (NH was replaced to N CH3). These results indicated that the free C-9 OH group and the NH-group of the amide were both important for high enantioselectivity and reactivity. Furthermore, 3 ua with free OH group at C-6′-position provided low enantioselectivity (43% ee) and reactivity (51% yield) compared with 3 u. 3ub (with isopropyl at C-6′ position) could not improve the enantioselectivity compared to 3 u. These results indicated the steric hindrance at NH-position (not C-6′) was crucial for high enantioselectivity (Scheme 4 ). Based on the control experiments and previous reports [15b], a plausible transition state depicted in Scheme 5 was proposed. As can be seen from Scheme 5, two different types of interactionsmight exist: (1) an ion-pair interaction between the substrate and PTC; (2) multiple hydrogen bonding interactions among catalyst, pyrazolone and N-trifluoromethylthiosaccharin. Our proposed model of the transition state posits that the pyrazolone substrate is stabilized by the hydrogen bond from the amide function of the catalyst. Moreover, the hydroxyl group of the catalyst forms an hydrogen-bond interaction with the oxygen of N-trifluoromethylthiosaccharin. Consequently, the SCF3 group can reach the α-carbon atom of pyrazolone exclusively from Re-face to afford the R-product. A key element determining the high enantioselective manner is the triphenyl group which blocks the Si-face of the enolate. This transition state can be supported by the study on the structure-activity relationship with a series of 9-OH and amide modified Cinchona alkaloids (Scheme 4). Conclusion In conclusion, we successfully carried out the enantioselective trifluoromethylthiolation of a wide range of 4-substituted pyrazolones using cheap and readily available amide-based Cinchona alkaloids with N-Trifluoromethylthiosaccharin as electrophilic reagent. Corresponding products with a quaternary chiral trifluoromethylthiol-attached carbon center were easily obtained in high yields (up to 98%) with good enantioselectivities (up to 88% ee). Controlled experiments showed that the multiple hydrogen bonding interactions and the steric hindrance at NH-position were the primary causes for high enantioselectivity and reactivity. Furthermore, the Cinchona-derived amide-based phase-transfer catalysts could be easily separated from the reaction system and reused for such reaction without any significant loss of reactivity or enantioselectivity. With a simple operational protocol and low catalyst loading, this transformation provides a practical and efficient method for preparation of chiral trifluoromethylthiolated compounds. Furthermore, the study of structure-activity relationship will attract more attention for broaden the scope of asymmetric reactions with amide-based phase transfer catalysts. Supplementary Material General remarks, experimental procedures, characterization of products, copies of NMR spectra for new catalysts, chiral products, and HPLC chromatograms. coredata.dc:description: We successfully developed the first enantioselective trifluoromethylthiolation of 4-substituted pyrazolones catalyzed by amide-based Cinchona alkaloids with N-trifluoromethylthiosaccharin. A broad variety of chiral CF3S-pyrazolones were obtained in excellent yields with high enantioselectivities. Controlled experiments showed that the multiple hydrogen bonding interactions and the steric hindrance at NH-position were indispensable for high enantioselectivity and reactivity. Furthermore, these amide-based phase transfer catalysts could be easily recovered and reused for such a reaction with almost original reactivity and enantioselectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Enantioselective trifluoromethylthiolation of 4-substituted pyrazolones catalyzed by amide-based phase transfer catalysts
